WRITING.TITLE: "Only the present moment is real" vs. "current suffering isn't real because it's impermanent, i.e. will be gone in the future" - a philosophical inconsistency?
WRITING.TEXT:
I asked this question **[here](https://www.reddit.com/r/Meditation/comments/5zdvp5/quote_from_the_power_of_now_eckhart_tolle/deyamx5/?context=10000)** but would like to pose the question in /r/buddhism as well and maybe get an answer:
I can't exactly wrap my mind around how it makes sense to focus on **"the power of now"**, and in all Buddhist philosophy it's always about "the past is no longer there, the future is not yet there, there is only **now**"... yet the main tool to reduce suffering is to focus one's attention on the impermanence of current suffering, i.e. on the fact that at some point *in the future* it will no longer be there.
That's a bit of a contradiction, isn't it?
It seems a bit like picking and choosing what actually matters. If the present is pleasant but people cry about the past, or are anxious about the future, Buddhist philosophy tells them to focus on the *now*, and that neither of those other tenses are currently real.
If someone is feeling pain in the present moment, Buddhist philosophy tells them to focus on the awareness that *at some point in the future* that pain will be gone.
I do experience the benefits of meditation, and I appreciate Buddhist philosophy as far as I'm familiar with it - but I can't quite make sense of this seeming contradiction. It seems like Buddhism promotes being either present-oriented or future-oriented in one's consciousness depending on what's more convenient at the time.
